news uk-news six-revelations-prince-andrew-summit-"Prince Andrew stripped of military titles and royal patronagesBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan  Prince Andrew has been left reeling after another disastrous week which saw him stripped him of his military titles and royal patronages less than  hours after being told her must face a civil trial. The move means Andrew has been completely removed from official royal le and he now have to face his future as an ­ordinary citizen. The scandal-hit Duke of York was informed that he will no longer use the title of His Royal Highness in any official capacity by the Queen on Thursday. It was another body blow after discovering the day before that New York judge Lewis Kaplan ruled Andrew must face a civil trial on allegations he ­sexually abused Virginia Giuffre when she was . He denies the accusations. Ms Giuffre, , who claims Andrew had sex with her on three occasions when she was just , has lived in Australia since .for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. He was summoned to meet his mother and told the news, but it wasnapost a decision made purely by Her Majesty. After hours of deliberation with other senior members of the Firm, a -minute meeting signalled the end of public royal le. But the summit is said to have not been straight-forward, with his lawyer left in the car park and the Prince left stunned by the outcome. Here are the six key revelations from Windsor Castle as it was decided the “axe should swtly fall” on Andrew’s royal career.aposFuriousapos Williamaposs part  Prince William has been ­“incandescent” at how his uncle has behaved throughout the legal saga. The Queen ruthlessly made her mind up on Wednesday, and she had some help coming to her conclusion.The Mirror ­understands the irate Duke is angry at his uncle for bringing the Royal Family into disrepute. A source said: “The Prince of Wales and Duke of Cambridge are completely aligned in their view that the Duke of York has presided over a complete and utter disaster.” It is believed detailed discussions within the family had been going on for weeks with William aware action was required.Andrew aposshell-shockedapos by decision  Andrew did not see the decision coming and one source described him as being “shell-shocked” at the move. The ruthless call came less than  hours after New York judge Lewis Kaplan ruled Andrew must face a civil trial. He denies the accusations. The source said he was stunned and added: “Given the robustness with which Judge Kaplan greeted our ­arguments, we are ­unsurprised by the ruling. “However, it was not a judgement on the merits of Ms Giuffre’s ­allegations. The Duke will continue to defend himself against these claims.” Queen told Andrew face-to-face  The Queen is understood to have broken the decision to middle son Andrew face-to-face. During a private audience, the monarch told her son he will no longer be known as His Royal Highness in any official capacity — and will be left to fight his lawsuit as a private citizen. Looking stony-faced, the Duke of York was driven a few miles from his house, Royal Lodge, to Windsor Castle on Thursday morning for the -minute sit down with his mum. She informed him of the decision and an official announcement was made hours later. Andrew apostried to bring lawyerapos to summit Prince Andrew attempted to bring his personal lawyer to the summit, sources say. He was driven to Windsor Castle by his brief Gary Bloxsome, but he was swtly told he would not be allowed inside with him. Instead, he waited outside in the car, the Daily Mail reports. Mr Bloxsomeaposs involvement may indicate Andrew had been taking legal advice before facing his mum. Queenaposs aposfinancial lelineaposPrince Andrew fears financial ruin amid the on-going sex case. Mounting legal bills and a potential £million settlement with his accuser has left him counting the cost of being banished from the royal family. But the Queen has offered her son a leline. She will not foot any legal bills, but sources have confirmed that Andrew will not lose his security detail. The Queen would privately meet the cost of his £, protectionhe is left broke.Discussions aposwent on for hoursapos The Queen and Prince William spoke atin her private quarters before the decision was reached. A royal source said last night the Duke of Cambridge was locked in talks “for more than an hour” with his gran. William, , is understood to have made sure no stone was left unturned. Prince Charles also played a part in the summit. He spoke to the Queen by phone from Scotland, where he is currently living. Andrew and the Queen spoke for more than  minutes, it was claimed, as she dropped the bombshell.Read MoreRead MoreFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Prince Charles, Prince of WalesThe QueenPrince Andrew, Duke of YorkPrince WilliamRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news six-times-prince-andrew-tried-"Prince Andrew addresses Virginia Giuffre’s allegations in ByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan Prince Andrew may finally have to answer key questions in the coming months over the sex abuse allegations which have seen him cast out into the cold. This week it was announced that the Queen had revoked his honorary military titles and can no longer use the title His Royal Highness. It comes after a US judged threw out his latest attempt to have a civil case brought by Virginia Giuffre thrown out. Ms Giuffre, now , claims that she was forced to have sex with the Duke three times when she was a apossex slaveapos of Andrewaposs paedophile pal Jeffrey Epstein as a teenager. The Duke of York vehemently denies the allegations. In recent weeks his legal team have tried numerous times to get the case thrown out, or to discredit Ms Giuffre, who they have claimed is seeking another payday at his expense.  Ms Giuffreaposs legal representative said his client is determined to face the royal in court after judge Lewis Kaplan said her civil case can proceed. The mum-of-three is seeking undisclosed damages from Andrew, who she was pictured with in an infamous photograph believed to have been taken in , when she was . It means Andrew could be compelled to answer questions about her claims in a civil court in the autumn. Here we look at some of the attempts the Duke and his team have made to prevent the court showdown from happening. . Claiming Virginia Giuffre may have  memoriesAs the Sunday Mirror reports today, Andrew’s lawyers want to quiz Ms Giuffre’s psychologist to seehis accuser is ­suffering from “ memories” of meeting HIM.The extraordinary move emerged in legal documents filed late on Friday in the Duke of York’s looming civil court battle with Ms Giuffre. But he claims he doesn’t remember meeting her – despite the infamous photo of him with his arm around her. It was quickly ridiculed by legal experts who described it as a “typical tactic” used in historic sexual abuse cases, and one Ghislaine Maxwell used at her trial.  But Andrew’s lawyers are determined to grill Ms Giuffre’s therapist Dr Judith Lightfoot on the “theory of  memories” as well as matters discussed during their sessions, notes taken and any prescriptions given. The lawyers state that the royal “contends that [Ms Giuffre] may suffer from  memories, as evidenced by the fact that her claims regarding her time with Epstein, and the circumstances under which [Prince Andrew] allegedly assaulted her, have repeatedly changed over the years”. The move bizarrely links to the Duke of York’s stance in his  car crash Newsnight interview where he claimed to have “no recollection” of meeting Ms Giuffre.. Attempting to rely on secret deal made with paedophile Jeffrey Epstein One avenue Andrewaposs legal team used to try and get the case thrown out was a , settlement made between Ms Giuffre and his former pal Epstein. In a  deal which was unsealed earlier this year, the financier and child trafficker agreed to pay Ms Giuffre after she accused him of sexual abuse. One key clause in the deal suggested that Ms Giuffre would be barred from taking action against any other parties linked to Epstein.  This, the Dukeaposs lawyers argued, would have included Andrew himself. The settlement included an agreement to remise, release, acquit, satisfy and forever discharge the said second parties and any other person or entity who could have been included as a potential defendant … from all, and all manner of, action and actions of Virginia , including state or federal, cause and causes of action”. But Judge Kaplan was having none of it. Epstein, he said, was only out to protect himself, he ruled, and this aspect of the agreement did not prevent Ms Giuffre from pursuing a civil claim against Andrew. Judge Kaplan said that settlement was too ambiguous to protect the royal. . Arguing Ms Giuffre could not sue as she lived in Australia Another technicality which Andrewaposs team hoped could prevent the case continuing was the fact that Ms Giuffre no longer lives in the US. This, lawyers claimed, meant that she could not legally take action through a US court.  The Dukeaposs lawyer Andrew B Brettler, called for the case to be halted at the end of last month. He wrote: “Recently discovered evidence suggests that the court does not have subject matter jurisdiction over this action because plaintf Virginia L Giuffre cannot satisfy the elements of ersity jurisdiction. “Notwithstanding that, in her complaint Ms Giuffre alleges she is a citizen of the state of Colorado the evidence demonstrates that she is actually domiciled in Australia, where she has lived for all but two of the past  years.” Again, this legal argument did not get very far. . aposHidingapos to prevent lawsuit being served on himBack when the civil case was launched, Andrew was accused of hiding to avoid the lawsuit being served on him.Security personnel repeatedly stopped officials trying to hand the Duke of York the documents at the Royal Lodge in August, it was claimed. Ms Giuffreaposs lawyers said the papers had been handed to a Met Police officer at the Royal Lodge in Windsor on August . But they claimed the agent was told police told them they were not able to accept served court papers, or let anyone serve them on the property. It led to Ms Giuffreaposs lawyers seeking intervention from Judge Kaplan, claiming Prince Andrew was playing game of hide and seek behind palace walls.  . Claiming not have met Ms GiuffreDuring his car-crash BBC Panorama interview back in , Andrew claimed he had no recollection of ever meeting Ms Giuffre.Rubbishing her allegations that she had been forced into having sex with him, Andrew said: I have no recollection of ever meeting this lady. None, whatsoever. He was pressed by interviewer Emily Maitlis, who asked him: You donapost remember meeting her  The Duke replied: No. Years earlier a photo had emerged of Andrew with his arms around Ms Giuffre with Ghislaine Maxwell in the background. However his circle have long suggested it is a fake - alleging that his fingers were not chubby enough to be his in the image. A palace source said Andrew has “absolutely no recollection” of the photo being taken and “seriously doubts” it is genuine. “Look at his fingers,” they said. “The duke has chubby fingers, they don’t look right, nor does the height of the duke and the girl. His legal team have asked to have the original photo so they can carry out their own investigation. They seriously doubt its veracity. The duke is adamant and has been consistent since  that he does not recall ever meeting Miss Roberts, let alone the photo being taken.” “Many close to the duke, who know him well, believe this is a witch-hunt based on absolutely no evidence.” . Pizza Express alibi and claims he could not sweat  Two of the claims in Andrewaposs  Panorama interview that drew the most attention were his claim that he was at a Pizza Express restaurant on one of the nights he is claimed to have had sex with Ms Giuffre - and his claim he cannot sweat. Quizzed about Ms Giuffreaposs claim that the prince sweated heavily on the night in , Andrew claimed to have a medical condition that meant he could not sweat. In legal documents related to the civil case, Ms Giuffreaposs lawyers David Boies and Sigrid McCawley called on the Duke to hand over all documents concerning your alleged medical condition of anhidrosis, hypohidrosis, or your inability to sweat. His lawyers refused, however, on the grounds that it is harassing and seeks confidential and private information and documents that are irrelevant, immaterial and not reasonably calculated to lead to the discovery of admissible evidence. Similarly the Duke has not presented any evidence proving he was at Pizza Express on March ,  - the night Ms Giuffre claims he partied in a West End nightclub before having sex with her. His lawyers responded: “Defendant is unable to comply with Request No.  because no such documents exist in his possession, custody or control. A diligent search and a reasonable inquiry have been made in an effort to comply with this demand.”Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Prince Andrew, Duke of YorkRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: sniffing your milk instead using
story: Snfing your milk instead of using best-before dates can cut m pints of food wasteMore than  million pints are tipped down the sink each year because of overly cautious dates - it is the third most wasted item in the UKGiving your milk a snf can tell youits gone off Image: Getty ImagesopinionByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  Jan | commentsHow many times have you opened the fridge to find your milk has passed the use-by date but is perfectly fine to drink  Giving it a good snf normally tells youit has turned sour, but more than  million pints are ­unnecessarily tipped down the sink each year because of overly cautious dates. Research by the University of Chester also found milk from Tesco, Sainsbury’s, Asda and Morrisons, kept unopened in a fridge set at C, remained safe to drink days after its use-by date. Now, in a victory for the environment and common sense, Morrisons says use-by dates on its milk cartons are to become a thing of the past. At the end of the month, the ­supermarket will instead be printing best-before dates on dairy products and encouraging people to do a “snf test”.  It comes as figures revealed that milk is the third most wasted food and drink item in the UK, with more than half a million tons of dairy chucked every year, most of that in the home. Nearly % of us are still confused by best-before and use-by dates. As supermarket foods carry wildly dferent information on how long they will last – some by as much as five months for the same items – it is not dficult to see why. Take a look through your kitchen cupboards and you will find “once-opened” instructions on similar items that are inconsistent and unclear as to whether they are recommendations on food safety or quality. The use-by date is about safety and the most important thing to remember. Foods can be eatenup until the use-by date but not after. Best before refers to the quality and taste. The food is most likely safe to eat after this date but may not be at its best in terms of flavour and texture. You can’t beat looking, smelling and tasting for a reliable indicator of how fresh the food is. But it would be even better for ­supermarkets and manufacturers to come up with a standard labelling system that was clear, consistent and easy to understand – to stop any more perfectly edible food ending up in the bin. title: stay your guard surprise signs
story: Stay on your guard for the surprise signs of gallstones with NICE guidanceUp to one in six people have ­gallstones without knowing it so it’s vital to know what you’re dealing with, writes the Mirrors Dr Miriam StoppardThe clincher is pain felt classically in the right shoulder Image: Getty ImagesopinionByMiriam Stoppard:,  Jan | commentsMost won’t have ­symptoms or need treatment, but for some the pain is so severe it can be mistaken for a heart attack. So it’s vital to know what you’re dealing with and there are ­official new guidelines from NICE for treating gallstones and gallbladder disease. How do gallstones form  They’re thought to be the result of too much cholesterol in your gallbladder, which is a small pouch near your liver that collects bile from it. Gallstones are more common the older you get – women, overweight people and over s are most at risk. Biliary colic is a particularly severe form of abdominal pain and it’s ­iniably due to gallstones. If infection of the gallbladder ­ occurs or a stone gets lodged in the biliary duct, which is the exit tube, that’s when the pain can be mistaken for a heart attack. Sudden pain under the right ribs, temperature, sickness and vomiting with pain lasting longer than eight hours warrants urgent admission to hospital. It’s these episodes of pain that are called biliary colic. It’s ­important to pin down a diagnosis of gallstones as ­complications such as pancreatitis and sepsis may arise, says Sandra Hapca of ­Aberdeen University. The clincher is pain felt classically in the right shoulder as inflammation irritates a nerve that stretches into your neck. Gallstones can be identied with an ultrasound.  The latest advice from NICE ­recommends keyhole surgery to remove the gallbladderyou have uncomplicated gallstones as we can live without a gallbladder. A watch and wait approach is only a stopgap measure. That’s due to the risks of recurring biliary colic and complications, the commonest of which is infection – acute cholecystitis. At one time a low-fat diet was recommended for anyone with gallstones but good evidence in support of it is scarce. Even though biliary pain is severe, relief with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugshas been found to be as effective as opiates. So paracetamol and diclofenac are first-line treatments. Experts believe treatment with antibiotics isn’t helpful in biliary colic. When any infection has settled it’s best the gallbladder is removed with a cholecystectomy, which is a common operation and most patients do well. Patients should be warned about discomfort and indigestion after the operation, which is known as post-cholecystectomy syndrome. This may be a reaction to the absence of your ­gallbladder. news uk-news uk-weather-forecast-exact-day-"UK Weather: Met Office forecast frostByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThe Met Office has issued an update on when snow will hit the UK as freezing temperatures are set to last all week. Temperatures will plunge below zero before Brits see any of the white stuff - which forecasters say will last some regions of the isles on Friday, January .Forecasters see the mercury plunging to lows of -C over the next seven days with the chill remaining in the low single-digits every night and reaching just over the C mark in daylight hours. WXChart meteorologists predict snow will be first seen in Scotland before moving South to northern England, according to The Sun Online. East Anglia is predicted to be hit with wintry showers early on January , before parts of the country between Aberdeen and Hampshire will then see snow on Sunday January .The arctic chill follows the trend of recent days after the Met Office warned of -C conditions amid blanketings of thick icy fog on Friday.During the day, temperatures will be milder hours this week will see milder temperatures, reaching as high as C in the southwest while generally staying around the  or C mark.  But as night approaches the cold will take hold with bone-shaking chills of -C seen in Wales on the coldest night of the week, which looks set to be the early hours of Tuesday morning. The Met Office has also predicted snow for the first half of February. Their long-range forecast reads: Into February outbreaks of rain and stronger winds are likely at times across the far north, whereas settled conditions are likely to persist in the south.  Temperatures are looking to be slightly above average, particularly in the north however some colder interludes remain likely, bringing a risk of occasional snow, most likely over northern hills. Five-day forecast Tonight: Most areas dry with long clear periods and fog patches. Cloudier and windier in the far north with some rain at times. Colder than last night with widespread frost. Monday: A chilly start then most areas fine, dry and bright with plenty of sunshine once early fog patches clear. Cloudier in the very far north with rain at times.  Outlook for Tuesday to Thursday: A cold and foggy start for some on Tuesday, with sunny spells developing. Rain arrives into the northwest later, sinking south but weakening through Wednesday. Thursday, dry with sunny spells. cold paves way for a snow blast at the end of the month. Met Officer forecasters see the mercury plunging to lows of -C over the next seven days with the chill remaining in the low single-digits every night and reaching just over the C mark in daylight hours. The freezing conditions will lead the way for snowfall, which looks set to blast some regions of the isles on Friday, January . WXCharter meteorologists say snow will be first seen in Scotland before moving south to northern England, according to the Sun Online.East Anglia is predicted to be hit with wintry showers early on January , before parts of the country between Aberdeen and Hampshire will then see snow on Sunday January .  The looming arctic chill follows the trend of recent days after the Met Office warned of -C conditions amid blanketings of thick icy fog on Friday. Daylight hours this week will see milder temperatures, reaching as high as C in the southwest while generally staying around the  or C mark. But as night approaches the cold will take hold with bone-shaking chills of -C seen in Wales on the coldest night of the week, which looks set to be the early hours of Tuesday morning.  Birmingham and London look set for lows of C on that freezing morning as Swindon plunges to freezing point. Temperatures in the east of England will struggle to stay over the zero mark, with C conditions likely. This cold front will be seen all the way up the east coast, hitting York and Newcastle upon Tyne. Today, Brits in Scotland and Northern Ireland will be able to bask in some winter sun as conditions stay generally dry across the UK, but with some chance of rain in the far south of England and central UK this afternoon.  The cold snap will arrive tonight with noticeably chillier conditions that will lead to widespread frost by tomorrow morning. Monday will start cold, but be generally dry with the chance of rain in the very far north.Last Friday, the Met Office urged everyone to get the hot water bottles at the ready as itaposs set to be a cold and frosty night amid reports of brutally cold -C night ahead.Despite temperatures plummeting, Brits shouldnapost expect any snow yet. MET OFFICE OUTLOOK Today: Sunny spells today, best of the sunshine across Scotland and Northern Ireland. Dry for many but some early showery rain in the far south and a little rain at times for northern England this morning and central UK this afternoon. Tonight: Most areas dry with long clear periods and fog patches. Cloudier and windier in the far north with some rain at times. Colder than last night with widespread frost. Monday: A chilly start then most areas fine, dry and bright with plenty of sunshine once early fog patches clear. Cloudier in the very far north with rain at times. Outlook for Tuesday to Thursday: A cold and foggy start for some on Tuesday, with sunny spells developing. Rain arrives into the northwest later, sinking south but weakening through Wednesday. news weird-news man-bemused-after-finding-hes-"TikToker spoilt rotten by cabin crew after being alone on flightByJohn BettAudience WriterSofie JacksonVideo News Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A man was left bemused after getting on a plane and finding he was the only passenger onboard - and he was then doted on by the cabin crew. Kai Forsyth, said it was the weirdest experience to be on the British Airways flight alone, but added heaposd never been comfier as he set up a bed across a few of the seats. He said he was given all the food that he wanted on the flight from London to Orlando, Florida, and cabin crew explained that no other passengers were on the plane, as the Daily Star reports. Kai, from Debry, shared his experience on TikTok, where he uploads to the account @kaorsyth, and now heaposs gone viral as fans canapost believe his luck. Whataposs your most unusual travel experience  Let us know in the comments...In the social media clip, Kai said: The cabin crew said I was the only person on board the flight. He said that he decided to put the armrests down and get comfy with a makesht bed across four empty seats. It was eight hours so I set up a bed. Literally the comfiest Iaposve ever been on a plane, he writes on the screen. Kai also shows how he was given a wholesale box full of Walkers shortbread biscuits since there was nobody  to cater for. They literally gave me all the snacks and unlimited food, he writes while making his viewersapos mouths water with jealousy. He said he couldnapost be upgraded to business or first class which was the only downside to his enjoyable trip. The video was watched more than , times and people said Kai was very lucky, although one confessed they found it a bit scary and said: Nah Iaposd be too paranoid the whole journey. A second viewer shared: I remember the flight home from JFK to Gatwick, about  people the whole of economy. Was the best flight. Omg that was me I kept flying when Covid first ever got announced and there were no restrictions, someone  commented. Another user said: The last time it happened to me it was the roughest flight ever and landed on nd attempt.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: man reviews biggest tea brands
story: Man reviews biggest tea brands in UK - and announces an unlikely winnerLewis Smith, journalist for Wales Online, decided to settle one of the nations great debates and find out which brand of tea is the best of them all - and his verdict might upset one or two peopleLewis reviewed each of the most popular tea brands in the UK Image: Lewis SmithByLewis SmithJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsItaposs the nationaposs favourite drink by a long way, with nothing quite so British as waking up to a nice cuppa to start the day off right.We Brits love our tea, with a good old mug of English breakfast being our favourite type as boxes of the stuff sit in kitchens up and down the UK. But with so many dferent brands to choose from, sometimes itaposs impossible to know which type to go for in the supermarket. Luckily, a reporter for Wales Online has done the heavy lting for the rest of us, sitting down to a proper tea tasting test to determine the best brand. Reporter Lewis Smith sat down with six brands: Tetley, Twinings, Yorkshire Tea, PG Tips, Tesco Original and a special Welsh blend, Paned Gymreig.  For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Using ml of water and a splash of milk in each cup, Lewis judged the taste of each brew to figure out which was best. First sitting down with a mug of Paned Gymreig, Lewis noted its rich taste and golden brown flavour. Despite a fairly satisfying taste test, he admitted it didnapost blow me away, and gave it a respectable .  rating. Next Lewis sat down with a slightly more expensive brand, Twinings Everyday. But, despite the fact it could be described as premium, Lewis was underwhelmed by the taste of the cuppa and decided some of the cheaper brands were much tastier. Bearing in mind price versus taste, Lewis gave it an unimpressive rating of  . Next up was PG Tips, a well known and moderately priced teabag that is a firm favourite in many households. He noted the lovely smell that greeted him as he opened the box of teabags, and said the taste lived up to the aroma. After admitting he could sit around and drink PG Tips all day, he gave the brand  . His fourth cuppa was a mugful of Yorkshire Tea - which could be argued to be the most popular brand of tea in the UK.  But Lewisaposs verdict will leave many fans of the northern brew upset, as he gave it a measly rating of . . Explaining his reasoning, Lewis said: It was one of my least favourite drinks due to the uniquely robust flavour that was not to my preference. He did admit, however, that the cup of Yorkshire Tea looked more appealing than most others he tested. Cuppa number five was a blend of Tesco Original, which came in at a bargain price - and Lewis reckoned he got more than enough for his money. Describing the cuppa as incredibly light and rich, he said it was another brew he could sit and drink all day. In what could be a surprising verdict for many, he gave the Tesco cuppa a rating of . . Finally, Lewis poured himself a cup of Tetley tea, another firm UK favourite that has been on the shelves since . Describing Tetley as his previous go-to choice for a brew, he realised on this taste test that it didnapost offer the same quality of flavour heaposd had from the PG Tips and Tesco options. Still, he offered it a respectable . . After sitting down with each cuppa, Lewis was adamant that Tesco Original was his favourite cuppa - closely followed by PG Tips. As for family favourites like Yorkshire Tea and Twinings, he could take or leave them - which is likely to ide Brits around the country. title: mum baffled pink egg frying
story: Mum baffled by pink egg in frying pan - and shes warned not to eat itBeena Sarangdhar screamed after cracking an egg into a frying pan as it was completely pink, and after she shared a snap of it online she was warned not to eat itBeena Sarangdhar was horried after finding a pink egg in her frying panByJohn BettAudience WriterAdam May:,  Jan | comments A mum was left baffled after cracking eggs into a frying pan to make breakfast for her children - as one of the yolks was completely pink.Beena Sarangdhar, from Abbots Langley, Hertfordshire, screamed when she made the unusual discovery, but soon her horror turned to curiosity and she cracked the rest of the eggs.To her surprise, all the rest of them were fine so she took a photo of the pink egg and shared it online - and soon others were warning her not to eat it, as Herts Live reports. Beena told her children to stay away and did some research, and it emerged that the egg had turned pink due to a bacteria that can lead to serious illness in humans. What do you think of the pink egg  Let us know in the comments...Beena said: I fancied some egg yesterday and cracked open the egg in the frying pan as normal. Then as it fell into the pan I screamed as I have never seen a pink egg before. The kids came running to see what had happened and their reaction was typical, [they went] aposerrrrapos. Beena then found that the other eggs were completely fine - but it was something she had definitely never seen before. She added: I then cracked the other two eggs from the same box but they were normal. It was really weird because they were in date and just the last few left. Bought them from the local Asda in Watford. It did put me off for a second but after that everyone fancied some egg on toast! According to the US Department of Agriculture, a cloudy egg white is a sign the egg is very fresh, and a clear egg white is an indication the egg is ageing. But Pink or pearly egg whites indicate spoilage due to Pseudomonas bacteria, which can lead to headaches, swelling, and even pneumonia. Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. news weird-news tiktok-chefs-master-formula-perfect-"TikTok chef shares how to make homemade Nando’s burger for just £ByRia NewmanJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsNandoaposs is is a firm favourite among many Brits whether itaposs for a family meal, a quick pre-cinema dinner or even a cosy takeaway. And when the craving for Peri Peri chicken rears its head, nothing  quite his the spot. In recent years, Nandoaposs has even started selling its own-brand sauces, mayonnaise and other items in supermarkets so fans can recreate their recipes at home. But even armed with a bottle of hot Peri Peri sauce, you need the know-how to create a decent homage to Nandoaposs classics like their wraps or burgers. Luckily, a TikTok chef has figured out the exact recipe for putting together the Nandoaposs burger from the comfort of your own kitchen - and itaposll only set you back £, a fraction of the price of the real thing.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Bartek, , from London, insists his formula for the perfect Nandoaposs burger is even better than the real thing. The former bartender shot to fame on TikTok after learning how to cook during lockdown when he wasnapost able to work. Now he shares his unique recipes in videos, which have earned him thousands of followers on the . In order to recreate his chicken burger, he uses a burger bun made of garlic bread. He then tops it with homemade perinaise - a mixture of peri peri sauce and mayonnaise. On top of that is the salad of lettuce and tomatoes, before two peri peri chicken thighs which have been chargrilled. Even including an extra that would set you back a few quid in Nandoaposs, he adds grilled halloumi to the top of the burger before topping it all off with another slice of garlic bread. title: ufo spotter makes sighting earths
story: UFO spotter makes sighting in Earths orbit thats  per cent proofA UFO reportedly several times bigger than the International Space Station has been caught on camera and the sighting is " per cent proof that aliens are watching over Earth"A man believes he has found irrefutable evidence of an alien spaceship visiting earth Image: ufosightingsdailyByJohn BettAudience WriterCharles Wade-PalmerReporter:,  Jan | comments A UFO spotter says he has found  per cent proof that aliens are watching over Earth after a picture of the International Space Station was shared online. Scott Waring is a space buff and runs the website UFO Sightings Daily, and there he shared a blown-up version of the image where you could see a reddish object that he claims is an alien spacecraft. He said that after careful analysis, he was sure it wasnapost the moon, and whatever it was it was much, much larger than the ISS in the foreground, as the Daily Star reports.Scott said that he monitors the space stationaposs live stream and has done for the past six years, so he knows a rare sighting when he sees one. What do you think of Scottaposs sighting  Let us know in the comments...Publishing his find on Wednesday, stunned Scott said: Watch this live space station footage taken today and you will see a close up of a huge sphere UFO rising up in earths orbit. Itaposs not the moon. The moon is five times bigger and bright. This object is much smaller, oval in shape and has some unique red green colours to it. The teacher from Taiwan believes there is no other explanation for what was picked up on camera, other than an extraterrestrial controlled spaceship.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. Scott told his , readers: I and others have seen such UFOs orbiting Earths moon, but this event is a very rare one to see orbiting Earth. This UFO is several times bigger than the space station. Absolutely amazing catch and  per cent proof that aliens are watching over Earth. Scott recently thanked his audience for donating to his fundraiser so he could afford a brand new computer capable of meeting his UFO detective demands.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. news weird-news woman-mocks-date-how-eats-"Woman films date eating salad with his fingersByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsFirst dates are always a daunting experience. Sometimes they go great and other times... not so great. Such was the case for one woman, as her dateaposs eating habits left her cringed out. Sydney Kinney, from Iowa, was looking forward to her date with a guy she met on Tider, and all seemed to be going well until it was time to eat the main course. As she tucked into her dish, she looked over to her date and saw he was eating his salad with his hands.She posted a video of the man tucking into his meal on her TikTok @sydkinnn, where she said: I met this guy on Tinder and decided to go on a date with him. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. “This is how he ate his salad. Since being posted, the video has been liked more than , times and has received , comments from ided viewers, many of whom were shocked to see him eating with his fingers. One person said: I broke up with a guy before because my toddler ate better than him. Another wrote: Immediately no. A third commented: Oh gosh, boy bye. Someone : He’s not eating, he’s shovelling. Goodbye. However, a few people defended the guy and said she was a red flag for mocking and exposing him online. And  Whataposs the problem  asked one person. Another said: Red flag. Others informed her that itaposs common in some cultures to eat with your hands. He’s being himself plus some cultures eat with their hands, they wrote. Sydney later posted another video with the guy after giving him another chance, and was seen eating at a Mexican restaurant. More recent videos show Sydney calling the man her boyfriend, so it seems his eating habits didnapost scare her away.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: woman praises 69p aldi tea
story: Woman praises p Aldi tea for giving her the best sleep shes had in agesA woman struggling to sleep took to Facebook to share a wonderous tea she found in Aldi that gave her the best night sleep shed had in ages Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsWeaposve all struggled to drop off to sleep at one point or another. Whether itaposs a busy mind keeping you up or your phone, there are plenty of things you can try to successfully send you into the land of nod - like drinking herbal tea. One woman swears by the remedy and says that it has completely transformed her night.Lindsay says she tried Aldiaposs Diplomat Night Time tea to see whether it would help her drt off to sleep, and when she woke in the morning she was thrilled by how well sheaposd slept. She posted about the le-saving tea in the Aldi UK shoppers group on Facebook, and said: Best nights sleep Iaposve had in ages after this sleep tea.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. But Lindsey wasnapost the only one to speak highly of the tea as many others shared their positive testimonials on her post. One person said: Iaposve been taking the sleep one since  days ago and honestly it works better than sleeping pills and also works on my anxiety levels so I drink a cup here and then during the day....and the taste is lovely too!! Another wrote: I use the Twinnings one but will definitely be swapping to these saving £ a box. Thanks for sharing. A third wrote: I tried it last night and slept great. Could have been four nights of tossing and turning but Iaposm saying it was the tea. But not everyone was convinced by its sleep benefits as one person said although it tastes lovely it left her tired the next morning. They wrote: So I had this last night thinking it was going to be a miracle cure for my restless nights! Not sureI was fighting against it trying to prove it wrong or what. But I had the worst night ever! Soooo tired this morning. But I will give it the benefit of doubt and stick with it! I will either be a walking zombie by next weekend or I will be full of beans! Time will tell! On a plus note, it tastes lovely! The tea is flavoured with chamomile which is often thought to have calming properties. The full list of ingredients include: Flowering Tops , Chamomile Flowers , Liquorice Root , Lavender Flowers, Lime Flower, Tulsi Leaf, and Valerian Root. Aldi does warn that anyone suffering from hypertension should avoid the tea as it contains liquorice. And itaposs easy enough to whip up. Simply pour freshly boiled water over the teabag and leave for three minutes for it to do its thing. But one woman says to get the full benefits, you should use two teabags. You can purchase a box of  teabags for just p in the superstore. The Diplomat Sleep Tea is part of a new Aldi range with other options claiming to boost the immune system, help with digestion, and even give you a detox.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: woman texts date next day
story: Woman texts date next day to thank him - then realises hes still in the houseA woman who had one too many beers on a date woke up the next morning to thank him for a lovely evening - but his response took her by surprise and left her red-facedZoes funny story resonated with a lot of people Image: TikTok   @zoechappersByJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThe dating scene can be pretty tough in the age of apps and social media - but it can give people some brilliant stories to tell.Whether itaposs something theyaposve done to make themselves look foolish, or something youaposve said that you instantly regretted, the world of dating is turbulent, to say the least.But one TikToker who had a hilarious date - or rather, day after her date - has shared her funny story with followers after being left red-faced and in shock. After a Tinder date with a man which had gone well and left her with a sore head from one too many drinks, Zoe Chaplin sent her companion a text the morning after the date to thank him for a lovely evening. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here But his reply gave her a shock - as it had been sent from the next room. She captioned the video: When I had a tinder date stay over  got so drunk I text him saying thanks for a good night and he replies I’m still on your sofa, I put you to bed. After sharing her embarrassment with viewers, they were quick to praise her date for sleeping on the sofa and making sure she was safely in bed. In response, Zoe said: Not many men would do the same. But in another comment she added: So embarrassing going down stairs to him on the sofa. People were keen to find outthis decent man and Zoe had gone the distance, and askedthe pair had had a second date. Zoe wrote: This was a while ago, we dated for a bit but we went our separate ways in the end. Lots of people viewing the video saw themselves in Zoeaposs story, and reckoned it was something theyaposd do on a date. One person wrote: My kinda night, to which Zoe replied: Too much wine! title: mum 24 sheds 6st military
story: Mum, , sheds st with military workout regime after eating McDonalds every dayMum-of-one Alex Moore, , from Adelaide in Australia, gained five-and-a-half stone while pregnant with daughter Alora and found herself eating from fast food joint McDonalds "at least" once a day for four monthsAlex Moore, , stacked on the weight during her pregnancy and would eat McDonalds at least once a day Image: Jam Press @alexpaigemooreByOlivia Loveridge-GreenRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A mum who ate McDonaldaposs at least once a day during her pregnancy has lost an incredible six stone – thanks to a gruelling military-style workout regime.Alex Moore, , from Adelaide, Australia, gained five-and-a-half stone while pregnant with her daughter Alora, now -months-old.Fed up with her “mum tum” and weighing st lbs, she decided to get in shape, swapping burgers for protein-rich meals. Following what she calls a strict military regime – which saw her take daily am visits to the gym and embark on km walks, working out for two-and-a-half hours a day – the mum-of-one managed to shed six stone in nine months.Despite being in better physical shape than before she had children, Alex says her meals are now bigger than what they were before – but packed with nutritious ingredients. She found out she was pregnant at the end of  and says midway through her pregnancy she began to eat unhealthily, causing her to pile on the pounds. “I really stacked on the weight – I was working long hours as a dental nurse and would eat McDonaldaposs at least once a day,” Alex, a former dental nurse, said.  I was starting early I’d usually get hash brown, egg and bacon muffin and hot chocolate for breakfast. And then for lunch I’d order a Quarter Pounder or Big Mac meal, a chocolate sundae and extra chicken nuggets with mayo. My mental health throughout most of my pregnancy was fine, however I did struggle towards the end realising how much weight I had gained and not recognising myself.” Alex welcomed her daughter in May  – but found herself feeling uncomfortable with her body. She said: I didnapost want to go out anywhere to show her off, I just wanted to hide away. I felt guilty Iaposd given birth to a beautul baby girl but I was so embarrassed about how I looked so never wanted my picture taken with her. I constantly heard was aposyour body will never be the sameapos and aposyou will always have a mum tum, learn to love itapos.  I didnapost want to be like that, so I used it as motivation. Alex decided that enough was enough and began to get in shape by hitting the gym and overhauling her diet. She said: I worked my a** off at the gym going at am every morning and going for km walks every day. At first I was really strict on my diet. I probably went too hard and developed somewhat of an eating disorder.  Iaposve now worked out a healthy relationship with food and exercise. Before I was only eating three small meals a day. Now I have larger meals and snacks. I donapost really count macros, or calories. I just try to eat mainly whole foods, regularly. I eat three main meals a day and have a snack in the morning which may be a protein bar, protein shake or a bit of fruit. In the afternoon I snack on a yoghurt but I try to listen to my body. I no longer turn down opportunities to eat out, and enjoy treats without guilt.  Alongside her healthy diet, Alex decided to ditch cardio and HIIT workouts in favour of weight training in a bid to gain lean muscle. She has currently shed six stone – and is healthier than ever. Her impressive weight loss has even let Alex change careers, swapping dental nursing for the glamourous le of an OnlyFans model.  She said: I saw it as a good source of income being a single mum having my daughter majority of the time. Now I can spend my days with Alora, and still make a good income. Alex shared a video documenting her weight loss to her , TikTok followers, who showered the mum-of-one with praise. One TikTok user said: This is what hard work and discipline looks like queens! Good job mumma. A second follower added: I literally gasped, this is amazing. Such an amazing transformation. Well done,” said another fan. One inspired viewer commented: Youaposre doing amazing Alex, itaposs empowering watching you.” While someone  said: Yes mama. You look awesome. Speaking about how her journey may inspire others, Alex added: I really want to show other mums what you can achieve when you set goals and are determined enough to achieve them. I also want people to know that itaposs important not to neglect self-care just because youaposre a mother – youaposre allowed to treat yourself and do things just for yourself. news world-news north-korea-accused-cultural-appropriation-"North Korea accused of appropriating Latino cultureByMichael HavisGraeme Murray:,  Jan | commentsNorth Korea has been accused of “appropriating Latino culture” by taking credit for the invention of the burrito. Recent propaganda from the secretive state featured a suspiciously burrito-like dish called a “wheat wrap”, allegedly invented in  by Kim Jong-il – the current leaderaposs father and predecessor. Kim Jong-un was also said to take a “meticulous interest” in the foodstuff, whose popularity was reportedly “booming” in Pyongyang. But now a civil rights group representing Latin Americans has blasted the oppressive regime for the boast, warning “don’t mess with our burritos”. The League of United Latin American Citizens , the largest and oldest Latino civil rights group in the US, said there had been an “explosive reaction” ranging from Texas to Calornia.  “Kim Jong-un is feeding into a delusionhe thinks North Korea can wake up one morning and appropriate our Latino cultural identity,” said LULAC boss Domingo Garcia. “The fact is Mexicans have been building and eating real burritos for hundreds of years.” He continued: “The origin of burritos is steeped deep in our history back to the days of the tamal in the Aztec civilisation.  “The women would place pieces of dried meat inside a moist ball of cornmeal and wrap it in a cornhusk. “In time, the cornmeal masa was replaced by a corn or flour tortilla, which evolved into the modern-day burrito. “You might call it the first take-out food of the Americas.”Mr Garcia rounded off by saying North Korean burritos were no match for the real thing.“Imitation is the best form of flattery,” he said. “But thereaposs no way that a street vendor in Pyongyang who has never even seen a tortilla comal is going to be able to compete with Abuelitaaposs [granny’s] best, made-from-scratch, piping hot burritos. “They look pretty skimpy from the television footage, and real burritos are bursting with all the meat, rice, beans and avocado packed into them. “North Korean and Mexicano burritos aren’t even in the same class.  “Sorry Kim Jong-un, you don’t get a free pass on this one.” The outburst comes after the Kim regime broadcast propaganda showing North Koreans devouring wheat wraps at a stand outside the Kumsong Food Factory in Pyongyang. The broadcast also showed a mural of Kim Jong-il grinning in a kitchen where the burrito-like wraps were being prepared. However there are some dferences between the North Korean dish and its Tex-Mex cousin.  For example, the Pyongyang version seems to contain some kind of doner meat, with what appears to be a mix of cabbage and carrot. Kim Jong-il advised that they are best accompanied by mineral water in the summer and hot tea in the winter, according to North Korea’s Rodong Sinmun newspaper.  The original, meanwhile, typically contains beef, chicken or pork alongside rice, beans and other ingredients. The exact provenance of the modern burrito is unclear, however the word burrito appears in an  Mexican dictionary, where it is described as a foodstuff. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. title: pioneering-glasgow-doctor-margaret-kerr-saved-lives-hundreds-premature-babies
story: COMPASSIONATE and dedicated, Dr Margaret Kerr’s work in Glasgow saved the lives of hundreds of premature babies. The consultant paediatrician at what was then the Royal Hospital for Sick Children at Yorkhill was a leading light in neo-natal medicine. She once said in an interview with the Evening Times: “I love babies – we are no longer just saving le but producing healthy future citizens. That gives us all pride and pleasure.”

title: farmers face fertiliser price standoff
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: end bedtime story benefits reading children keig aberdeenshire
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: aberdeen detached home walled gardens 460k
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
